title: 112_s378
content: The Act may be cited as the "Incentives to Educate American Children Act of 2011" or the "I Teach Act of 2011." Congress finds that classrooms are increasingly filled with less experienced teachers due to retirements and decreasing retention rates. Research shows that more years of teaching experience positively impact student achievement. Additionally, 32 percent of public schools are in rural districts. Rural school districts face increased transportation costs, leading to less money for instructional costs and salaries. Data shows they have the lowest base salaries for teachers. High poverty high schools are twice as likely to lack certified teachers in their fields. First year teacher rates are higher in high poverty schools, including rural schools. The National Board for Professional Teaching Standards, established in 1987, sets high standards for accomplished teachers. Over 91,000 teachers nationwide have completed certification through this rigorous assessment process. The National Academies confirmed that students taught by National Board certified teachers show higher achievement test gains compared to those taught by non-certified teachers. A study by the Economic Policy Institute revealed that public school teachers earn 77% less than other college graduates, with the gap widening. The Act aims to incentivize teachers to work in rural or high-poverty schools through a refundable tax credit and provide additional tax credits for National Board certification. The Act aims to incentivize teachers to achieve certification from the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards to recruit and retain highly qualified teachers in public schools. Tax credit for individuals teaching in high poverty or rural areas and certified teachers is introduced in the Internal Revenue Code to incentivize qualified teachers in public schools. Tax credit for eligible teachers in public schools teaching in rural areas or high poverty schools allows a credit against the tax imposed for the taxable year equal to $1,000. The tax credit for eligible teachers in public schools teaching in rural areas or high poverty schools is $1,000. Eligibility criteria include schools where at least 75% of students receive free or reduced-cost lunches or have a School Locale Code of 41, 42, or 43. Teachers certified by the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards for the academic year are eligible for the credit. The applicable amount for eligible teachers in high poverty schools is $2,000. An eligible teacher is defined as a full-time kindergarten through grade 12 classroom teacher in a public elementary or secondary school for any academic year after December 31, 2011. The applicable amount for eligible teachers in high poverty schools is $2,000. An eligible teacher is defined as a full-time kindergarten through grade 12 classroom teacher in a public elementary or secondary school for any academic year beginning after December 31, 2011. Conforming Amendments include changes to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Tax credit for individuals teaching in high poverty or rural areas and certified teachers. Effective Date: Amendments apply to academic years ending in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011.
